title: Persistent XSS via e-mail when creating merge requests

profile.name: GitLab
profile.about: A single application for the entire software development lifecycle.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:**
The vulnerability consists in the ability to create branch names that contain characters such as `<>/`. This branch name is sent via e-mail which is rendered as HTML.

**Description:**
One way to exploit this is by forking a repository. Then an attacker would create a branch called `<script>alert(1)</script>` and make a simple change. Now the attacker creates a merge request to the original repository and assign a reviewer to it. The reviewer will receive the e-mail with the branch name not sanitised. 

Another way to exploit is to by adding Gitlab users to a repository the attacker controls and assign them to review merge requests.

## Steps To Reproduce:

Note: These instructions work on GDK with the latest version. I wasn't sure if it is allowed to test something like on gitlab.com

  1.  Choose a public repository and fork it (let's say HTML5 boilerplate)
  2. Go through the repository main page http://yourserver:3000/root/html5-boilerplate
  3. Click on the button + button and select New File
  4. Create any file but choose a different target branch (something like <script>alert(1)</script>
  5. Gitlab will direct you to a page to create a new merge request from your recently create branch to master. Ignore that.
  6. Open a New Merge Request
  7. Select Source Branch as your fork and the recently created branch
  8. As for Target branch select the original repo and master
  9. Click submit
10. Select one the maintainers of the original repo 
11. Submit
12. Go to letter opener (/rails/letter_opener/)
13. See the alert popping up.

The steps above only require UI, but an attacker can create a branch name through git client as well. The create branch option UI protects against this attack.

There is also another version of the attack, where a repository owner can add any Gitlab users to become members of her repo. The attacker now create a Merge Request in his own repo and assign the new member to it. Same result. 

## Supporting Material/References:

* Vulnerable code at `gitlab-ce/app/views/notify/new_merge_request_email.html.haml` line 6. This is the exploit above.
* Vulnerable code at `gitlab-ce/app/views/notify/repository_push_email.text.haml` line 49. I haven't created an exploit for this one, but I would assume it should be similar.

## Impact

E-mail clients nowadays are well protected against XSS. However, a malicious user could use Gitlab's name to mislead users. The problem with this vulnerability is the reach. It is my understanding, an attacker can add whoever is a Gitlab user as a member of her own repo. So she could send malicious e-mails to them. I would usually say that is a low vulnerability, however, given the number of users that could be affected I would say is a medium
vulnerability_information_html:
Summary:
The vulnerability consists in the ability to create branch names that contain characters such as <>/. This branch name is sent via e-mail which is rendered as HTML.

Description:
One way to exploit this is by forking a repository. Then an attacker would create a branch called <script>alert(1)</script> and make a simple change. Now the attacker creates a merge request to the original repository and assign a reviewer to it. The reviewer will receive the e-mail with the branch name not sanitised.

Another way to exploit is to by adding Gitlab users to a repository the attacker controls and assign them to review merge requests.

Steps To Reproduce:

Note: These instructions work on GDK with the latest version. I wasn't sure if it is allowed to test something like on gitlab.com

  1. Choose a public repository and fork it (let's say HTML5 boilerplate)
  2. Go through the repository main page http://yourserver:3000/root/html5-boilerplate
  3. Click on the button + button and select New File
  4. Create any file but choose a different target branch (something like <script>alert(1)</script>
  5. Gitlab will direct you to a page to create a new merge request from your recently create branch to master. Ignore that.
  6. Open a New Merge Request
  7. Select Source Branch as your fork and the recently created branch
  8. As for Target branch select the original repo and master
  9. Click submit
    1. Select one the maintainers of the original repo
    2. Submit
    3. Go to letter opener (/rails/letter_opener/)
    4. See the alert popping up.

The steps above only require UI, but an attacker can create a branch name through git client as well. The create branch option UI protects against this attack.

There is also another version of the attack, where a repository owner can add any Gitlab users to become members of her repo. The attacker now create a Merge Request in his own repo and assign the new member to it. Same result.

Supporting Material/References:

  • Vulnerable code at gitlab-ce/app/views/notify/new_merge_request_email.html.haml line 6. This is the exploit above.
  • Vulnerable code at gitlab-ce/app/views/notify/repository_push_email.text.haml line 49. I haven't created an exploit for this one, but I would assume it should be similar.

Impact

E-mail clients nowadays are well protected against XSS. However, a malicious user could use Gitlab's name to mislead users. The problem with this vulnerability is the reach. It is my understanding, an attacker can add whoever is a Gitlab user as a member of her own repo. So she could send malicious e-mails to them. I would usually say that is a low vulnerability, however, given the number of users that could be affected I would say is a medium

activities.message:
Hi @mario-areias,

Thank you for submitting this report. We will investigate the issue as soon as possible.
Due to our current workload, we will get back within 14 business days with an update.

Please refrain from submitting your report or inquiring about its status through
additional channels, as this unnecessarily binds resources in the security team.

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

activities.message:
Hello @mario-areias ,

I am having trouble correctly generating an email with the behavior described in the report.

Please provide the raw contents of the email as an attachment and a screenshot of the email.

Also, please clarify the second steps number 1-4 that appear to follow step 9.  What user account is performing these actions on what pages?  Full urls and/or screenshots of this would also help.

Regards,
Antony
activities.markdown_message:
Hello @mario-areias ,

I am having trouble correctly generating an email with the behavior described in the report.

Please provide the raw contents of the email as an attachment and a screenshot of the email.

Also, please clarify the second steps number 1-4 that appear to follow step 9. What user account is performing these actions on what pages? Full urls and/or screenshots of this would also help.

Regards,
Antony

Okay. Second try.
I tested this using GDK so I wouldn't spam users on gitlab.com

  1. Go to any public repo. For example:
    http://yourserver:3000/h5bp/html5-boilerplate

  2. Fork it to a namespace you own.
    http://yourserver:3000/root/html5-boilerplate

  3. Create a new file through the UI like the picture below. It should redirect to: http://yourserver:3000/root/html5-boilerplate/new/master

  4. Add any file. Content does not matter. Change the target branch to <script>alert(1)</script>

  5. After clicking in Commit changes, Gitlab will redirect to create a merge request from this newly created branch to master. Ignore that step.

  6. Create a different merge request from the local branch <script>alert(1)</script> to original repo master, like below.
    http://yourserver:3000/root/html5-boilerplate/merge_requests/new

  7. Assign a person to review your merge request and submit it.

  8. Go to letter opener.
    http://yourserver:3000/root/html5-boilerplate/rails/letter_opener/

Let me know if that is enough.

activities.message:
Hello,

Thank you for submitting this report.

We have verified this finding and have escalated to our engineering team.  We will be tracking progress internally at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ce/issues/58505.  This issue will be made public 30 days following the release of a patch.

We will continue to update you via HackerOne as a patch is scheduled for release.

Best regards,
Security Team | GitLab Inc.

Best regards,
Security Team | GitLab Inc.

activities.message:
ETA for fix:

Hi @mario-areias,

The GitLab issue created from your report is currently scheduled for 2019-05-22.

Thank you again for contacting us!

Best regards,
GitLab Security Team

activities.message: Hi @asaba , this issue is also a problem on gitlab-ee as well. Although, I haven't created an exploit, the code seems very similar to the one in gitlab-ce.
activities.markdown_message: Hi @asaba , this issue is also a problem on gitlab-ee as well. Although, I haven't created an exploit, the code seems very similar to the one in gitlab-ce.

activities.message:
Yeah, just confirmed gitlab-ee has exactly the same vulnerabilites as gitlab ce and one addition as well. 
`./ee/app/views/notify/add_merge_request_approver_email.html.haml` line 5.
activities.markdown_message:
Yeah, just confirmed gitlab-ee has exactly the same vulnerabilites as gitlab ce and one addition as well.
./ee/app/views/notify/add_merge_request_approver_email.html.haml line 5.

activities.message:
Hi @asaba any updates on this? 

The bot said the issue was "currently scheduled for 2019-05-22". But I can't see the issue yet. Also, I noticed one of the files has been fixed in both `gitlab-ce` and `gitlab-ee`. But there are other files with the same issue (as described above). Given the fix is quite simple, I would _strongly_ recommend fix both of them. I can make a Merge Request if that helps. 

- Vulnerable code at `gitlab-ce/app/views/notify/repository_push_email.text.haml` line 49 in both `gitlab-ce` and `gitlab-ee`.
- Vulnerable code at `./ee/app/views/notify/add_merge_request_approver_email.html.haml` line 5
activities.markdown_message:
Hi @asaba any updates on this?

The bot said the issue was "currently scheduled for 2019-05-22". But I can't see the issue yet. Also, I noticed one of the files has been fixed in both gitlab-ce and gitlab-ee. But there are other files with the same issue (as described above). Given the fix is quite simple, I would strongly recommend fix both of them. I can make a Merge Request if that helps.

  • Vulnerable code at gitlab-ce/app/views/notify/repository_push_email.text.haml line 49 in both gitlab-ce and gitlab-ee.
  • Vulnerable code at ./ee/app/views/notify/add_merge_request_approver_email.html.haml line 5

activities.message:
Hello @mario-areias ,

Unfortunately, the additional locations were not relayed to the engineering team before the initial round of fixes, and the additional fixes have not been scheduled yet. The original linked issue will be confidential until 30 days after the additional fixes are made.

However, we have reviewed this finding for awarding a bounty prior the release of a patch. Congratulations!

We will continue to keep you updated via HackerOne as a fix is scheduled.

Best regards,
Security Team | GitLab Inc.

Regards,

activities.message:
Hello @mario-areias,

Now that it has been 30 days since a fix was released for this finding, we would like to publicly disclose this report.

Please note that [the GitLab issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-ee/issues/11515) for this report has now been set to public. If you see any sensitive information that needs to be redacted or removed in that GitLab issue or this report, please let me know here.

Thanks again for helping make GitLab more secure.

Have a great day,
Andrew
Security Team | GitLab

Thanks again!
